title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account. The Act allows depository institutions to permit account owners to make transfers between accounts, with a limit of 24 transfers per month. Amendments to Public Law 93-100 further specify the conditions for these transactions. The Act allows depository institutions to permit account owners to make transfers between accounts, with a limit of 24 transfers per month. Amendments to Public Law 93-100 specify conditions for these transactions, including restrictions on offering demand deposit accounts to institutions prohibited by law. The amendments made by paragraph (1) will take effect 2 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Prohibition on Payment of Interest on Demand Deposits from various acts including the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Joint rulemaking required. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act's Section 18(g) is repealed. The Secretary of the Treasury and Federal banking agencies must issue joint regulations allowing interest and dividends on transaction accounts at regulated depository institutions within 2 years. Regulations will define the scope of this authorization. Regulations required by this subsection shall establish the scope of the authorization for interest and dividends on transaction accounts at regulated depository institutions, including limitations and effective date within 2 years of enactment. The regulations required by this subsection, which include definitions for "depository institution," "transaction account," and "Federal banking agency," must be in effect within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The term "Federal banking agency" is defined in section 3 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The amendments will become effective 2 years after the enactment of the Act or when final regulations under subsection (b) become effective. SEC. 4. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal reserve bank, paid quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may establish regulations regarding these payments and distributions. The Board may promulgate regulations concerning the payment and distribution of earnings to depository institutions maintaining balances at Federal reserve banks. The Board may regulate the distribution of earnings to depository institutions holding balances at Federal reserve banks, including responsibilities of various entities for crediting and distributing earnings. The Federal Reserve Bank authorizes pass-through reserves for member banks, including various types of depository institutions defined under the paragraph. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to authorize pass-through reserves for member banks, with technical and conforming amendments made to the Act. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to authorize pass-through reserves for member banks, with technical amendments made to the Act by redesignating subparagraphs and subsections. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to give the Federal Reserve Board more flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent and may even be zero. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts in real estate transactions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The Home Owners' Loan Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act exclude certain activities related to escrow accounts from being considered as interest payments. These activities include absorbing expenses, forbearing from charging fees, and providing benefits to the account holder or beneficiary. The Home Owners' Loan Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act exclude certain activities related to escrow accounts from being considered as interest payments, including any benefits accruing to the account holder or beneficiary from actions taken by the depository institution.
